standard_metadata.standard_description: Interpret and compute quotients of fractions, and solve word problems involving division of fractions by fractions, e.g., by using visual fraction models and equations to represent the problem.

question.content: Use the number line to answer the following $2$ questions.    1. **How many groups of $\dfrac{5}{7}$ are in $1$?**   groups  2. **Evaluate.**  $8\div \dfrac{5}{7}=$

images.alt: A number line from 0 to 11 sevenths with evenly spaced tick marks in increments of 1 seventh.  0 and 1 are labeled below the number line.  0 sevenths, 1 seventh, 2 sevenths, 3 sevenths, 4 sevenths, 5 sevenths, 6 sevenths, 7 sevenths, 8 sevenths, 9 sevenths, 10 sevenths, and 11 sevenths are labeled above the number line.  There is a teal line on the number line that begins at 0 sevenths and ends at 5 sevenths.  There is an orange line on the number line that begins at 5 sevenths and ends at 7 sevenths.  Above the number line is a fraction model with 10 equal parts.  5 parts are shaded teal, 2 parts are shaded orange, and 3 parts are white. The number of color blocks of the fraction model correspond to the length of the colored sections on the number line.

hints.content: ###Strategy  We can count the number of groups of $\blueE{\dfrac{5}{7}}$ from the diagram. Since $\blueE{\dfrac{5}{7}}$ is less than $1$, we will expect to find more than $1$ group.  The expression $\purpleD{8}\div \blueE{\dfrac{5}{7}}$ can mean, "How many groups of $\blueE{\dfrac{5}{7}}$ are in $\purpleD{8}$?" There will be $\purpleD{8}$ times as many groups in $\purpleD{8}$ as there were in $1$.

###Counting the groups of $\blueE{\dfrac{5}{7}}$ in $1$  Since there are $7$ sevenths per $1$ unit, there are between $1$ and $2$ full groups of $\blueE{\dfrac{5}{7}}$ in $1$.   It takes $5$ parts for each full group, and there are $2$ parts left over, for a total of $7$ out of $5$ parts.  [[☃ image 1]]  There are exactly $\maroonD{\dfrac{7}{5}}$ groups of $\blueE{\dfrac{5}{7}}$ in $1$.   We call $\maroonD{\dfrac{7}{5}}$ the **reciprocal** of $\blueE{\dfrac{5}{7}}$.

images.alt: A number line from 0 to 11 sevenths with evenly spaced tick marks in increments of 1 seventh.  0 and 1 are labeled below the number line.  0 sevenths, 1 seventh, 2 sevenths, 3 sevenths, 4 sevenths, 5 sevenths, 6 sevenths, 7 sevenths, 8 sevenths, 9 sevenths, 10 sevenths, and 11 sevenths are labeled above the number line.  There is a teal line on the number line that begins at 0 sevenths and ends at 5 sevenths.  There is an orange line on the number line that begins at 5 sevenths and ends at 7 sevenths.  Above the number line is a fraction model with 10 equal parts.  5 parts are shaded teal, 2 parts are shaded orange, and 3 parts are white. The number of color blocks of the fraction model correspond to the length of the colored sections on the number line. 7 fifths groups of 5 sevenths is above the fraction model with a bracket that starts at the first part of the fraction model and ending after the seventh part of the fraction model.

hints.content: ###Finding the groups of $\dfrac{5}{7}$ in $\purpleD{8}$  There are $\maroonD{\dfrac{7}{5}}$ groups of $\blueE{\dfrac{5}{7}}$ in $1$.   So there are $\purpleD{8}\times \maroonD{\dfrac{7}{5}}$ groups of $\blueE{\dfrac{5}{7}}$ in $\purpleD{8}$.  $\begin{align} \purpleD{8}\div \blueE{\dfrac{5}{7}} &= \purpleD{8} \times \maroonD{\dfrac{7}{5}}\\\\ &= \purpleD{\dfrac{8}{1}} \times \maroonD{\dfrac{7}{5}}\\\\ &= \goldE{\dfrac{56}{5}} \end{align}$
###Summary  There are $\maroonD{\dfrac{7}{5}}$ groups of ${\dfrac{5}{7}}$ in $1$.   $8\div {\dfrac{5}{7}} = \goldE{\dfrac{56}{5}}$

hints.content: ###Summary  There are $\redE{16}$ groups of ${\dfrac{1}{2}}$ in $8$.   $8\div {\dfrac{3}{2}} = \dfrac{\redE{16}}{\maroonE{3}}$

question.content: Use the number line to answer the following $2$ questions.    1. **How many groups of $\dfrac{1}{5}$ are in $4$?**   groups  2. **Evaluate.**  $4\div \dfrac{6}{5}= $

images.alt: A number line from 0 to 4 and 4 fifths with evenly spaced tick marks in increments of 1 fifth.  0, 1, 2, 3, and 4 are labeled below the number line.  0 fifths, 6 fifths, 12 fifths, 18 fifths, and 24 fifths are labeled above the number line.  Above the number line is a fraction model with 24 equal parts.  12 parts are shaded teal, 8 parts are shaded orange, and 4 parts are white. The number of color blocks of the fraction model correspond to the length of the colored sections on the number line.

hints.content: ###Strategy  We can rewrite $\purpleD{4}$ as a number of fifths in order to find the number of groups of $\dfrac{1}{\tealE{5}}$ in $\purpleD{4}$.  The expression $\purpleD{4}\div {\dfrac{\maroonE{6}}{\tealE{5}}}$ can mean, "How many groups of ${\dfrac{\maroonE{6}}{\tealE{5}}}$ are in $\purpleD{4}$?" It takes $\maroonE{6}$ fifths to make a group of ${\dfrac{\maroonE{6}}{\tealE{5}}}$. So we can divide the number of fifths by $\maroonE{6}$.

###Counting the groups of ${\dfrac{1}{\tealE{5}}}$ in $\purpleD{4}$  We have $\purpleD{4}$ wholes.   The number line shows $\tealE{5}$ fifths per whole. So we have $\purpleD{4} \times \tealE{5}$ fifths.  [[☃ image 1]]  There are $\redE{20}$ groups of $\dfrac{1}{\tealE{5}}$ in $\purpleD{4}$.

images.alt: A number line from 0 to 4 and 4 fifths with evenly spaced tick marks in increments of 1 fifth.  0, 1, 2, 3, and 4 are labeled below the number line.  0 fifths, 6 fifths, 12 fifths, 18 fifths, and 24 fifths are labeled above the number line.  Above the number line is a fraction model with 24 equal parts.  12 parts are shaded teal, 8 parts are shaded orange, and 4 parts are white. The number of color blocks of the fraction model correspond to the length of the colored sections on the number line. 20 groups of 1 fifth is above the fraction model with a bracket that starts at the first part of the fraction model and ending after the twentieth part of the fraction model.

hints.content: ###Finding the groups of ${\dfrac{\maroonE{6}}{\tealE{5}}}$ in $\purpleD{4}$  It takes $\maroonE{6}$ fifths to make a group of ${\dfrac{\maroonE{6}}{\tealE{5}}}$.   So we have $\purpleD{4} \times \tealE{5} \div \maroonE{6}$ groups of $\dfrac{\maroonE{6}}{\tealE{5}}$.  $\begin{align} \purpleD{4}\div \dfrac{\maroonE{6}}{\tealE{5}} &= \purpleD{4} \times \tealE{5} \div \maroonE{6}\\\\ &= \redE{20} \div \maroonE{6}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\redE{20}}{\maroonE{6}} \end{align}$  [[☃ image 1]]  This makes sense, because the diagram shows $3$ full groups of $\dfrac{\maroonE{6}}{\tealE{5}}$ and $\dfrac{2}{6}$ of a group. That's equal to $\dfrac{\redE{20}}{\maroonE{6}}$ groups.
